Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Identification of Transport Barriers in Two-Dimensional Turbulence
Award.AbstractNarration:
Knowing the location and evolution of transport barriers within a fluid provides an important tool in predicting how particles disperse, a prime example being how an oil spill spreads on the ocean surface. A turbulent, two-dimensional fluid, like the surface of the ocean, can have distinct regions where the fluid does and does not mix, which determines how particles are transported across the surface of the fluid. Those non-mixing regions are known as transport barriers, as particles outside cannot move into or across the transport barrier. This project will use laboratory-produced two-dimensional turbulence to experimentally test and refine recently developed, novel mathematical methods for identifying transport barriers. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Hua Xia, an expert in experimental two-dimensional fluid turbulence, at Australian National University in Canberra, Australia.

Historically, identifying coherent structures (transport barriers) in a fluid by way of finite time Lyapunov exponents is an intensive task that requires detailed resolution of the fluid velocity field. Recently, mathematical methods for identifying coherent structures based on braid theory have been developed and applied to several test cases. These methods are advantageous as they can identify coherent structures from a small number of surface particle trajectories, decreasing the computational cost and increasing the method applicability. This research will implement and improve the braid-theoretic identification scheme by testing the algorithms with surface particle trajectories taken from experiments in which turbulence is driven by Faraday waves. This project aims to develop a computational framework that can then be applied in situ to surface particle trajectories both inside and outside of laboratory experiments.

This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A consequence of the nature of turbulent fluid flows is the seemingly chaotic and 
unpredictable movement of particles embedded within the flow.  Despite the 
inability to predict how individual microscopic particles evolve in turbulent flows, 
one is often interested in the evolution of macroscopic quantities, such as how 
collections of particles evolve.  In particular, for a two-dimensional fluid, such as a 
thin fluid film or the surface of a fluid like the ocean, the transport of particles 
across the fluid is of considerable interest.  For example, it is often important in 
industrial applications that different chemicals mix properly or it is important to 
know how particles disperse on the surface of a fluid, like an oil slick on the ocean.  
The behavior of such particles is closely tied to the behavior of the underpinning 
fluid and global transport can be significantly influenced by local fluid regions where 
the fluid moves coherently, which often acts as a barrier to transport.

Historically, identifying those coherent fluid regions, also referred to as coherent 
structures, is a difficult and expensive process.  One measurement technique that 
has only recently come to the fore relies of using the trajectories of fluid tracer 
particles, known as Lagrangian trajectories, to reconstruct coherent structures in 
the fluid.  Previously established Lagrangian coherent structure (LCS) 
identification methods require a high density of information to identify coherent 
structures from the dynamics of the tracer particles.  Recently, promising, new 
identification schemes using methods from the mathematical subject of braid 
theory have been developed and successfully applied to some simple numerical 
examples.  One significant advantage of this new method is that instead of 
relying on detailed information of the dynamics of large numbers of tracer 
particles, it uses only the topology of the tracer trajectories and is effective with a 
sparse data set.

The focus of this research has been to apply the braid-theoretic LCS 
identification scheme using tracer trajectories taken from real, physical 
two-dimensional turbulent flows produced at the Physics of Fluids Laboratory at 
The Australian National University.  A suite of analysis routines were written and 
optimized and applied to the turbulence data sets.  It was found that braid theory 
provides a significantly more efficient and robust way of characterizing the level of 
mixing within a two-dimensional fluid.  In particular, it was shown that only a 
small number of tracer particles are necessary to determine if a fluid is 
well-mixed.  This has immediate potential for application in industrial and 
commercial settings, in addition to providing the fluids research community with 
a robust tool for identifying mixing in fluids.  Application of the braid-theoretic 
LCS identification methods to the turbulent data suggests that the traditional 
way of thinking about particle trajectories in turbulence may need to be refined, 
as the braid-theoretic methods identified significant streaming of particles with 
each other for long time periods, as opposed to exponential divergence of 
trajectories.  This may provide a substantial insight into better understanding and 
developing fundamental turbulence theory.
